I actually ran my microwave without anything it for five minutes once 
because it smelled a little funky and I figured it'd get rid of the smell, 
even after I scrubbed the shit out of it. While it worked, it also 
overheated the microwave. I unplugged it and the plug was near melting and 
it has this big brown ring on the top now. But it still works! Like, just 
as well as it ever did, and the smell did go away, so there's that. Won't 
do that again, though, that's for sure.﻿

comments.author: Rachull

comments.text:
Anything containing metal, paper, or plastic seems like a no-brainer to 
microwave. Dried hot peppers also seem fairly obvious, but who would be 
microwaving that by itself? It would likely be included within some sort of 
meal, probably leftovers, and will already be rehydrated by then. The 
grapes were probably the only thing on the list that made me go "huh". Of 
course, I'm not sure why you would microwave grapes, dehyrated or 
otherwise, in the first place, but hey... it still gets you thinking, what 
exactly makes it go up in flames in a microwaved environment?﻿

comments.author: Gamer Elite

comments.text:
In seventh grade, I once microwaved my glasses (that had metal frames).
Story: I was trying to find a way to dry my glasses without having streaks 
all the time. So my brilliant 7th grade mind thought, "Hmmm, why don't I 
wet the glasses, stick it in the microwave and then the heat will evaporate 
the water and my glasses will be very clean!"

Well, the microwave started flashing all sorts of blue lol. And well, one 
of the arms on my glasses was all melted and I wore them for about a year 
before getting another pair. Haha.

So life lesson: Don't microwave your prescription glasses.﻿

comments.author: Claire Nelson

comments.text:
when I was about 10 I noticed that my favorite nail polish had dried out. 
And I got this ''fantastic'' idea that it might get more liquidy if I 
microwaved it. I smelled something burned and saw strange flashes in the 
microwave, so i opened the microwave and a thick grey smoke filled the 
house. Breathing it made the throat, lungs and nose burn. Luckily only me, 
my turtle and my brother were home, so we ran out of the house with our 
turtle and my laptop and opened all the doors/windows for the air to go 
out. it took 6 hours before we could walk inside and breathe in there 
again.. xD the only thing left of the nail polish was a black goo. and this 
happened many years ago and I accidently told my mom recently, her reaction 
was priceless.﻿

You CAN boil eggs in the microwave, just not like that! They have to be in 
a microwave-safe bowl completely submerged in water (not one area of egg

water.﻿
